thread.title: SF hospital tests new goo in walls to absorb earthquake shock
thread.title_full: SF hospital tests new goo in walls to absorb earthquake shock - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Benny Evangelista
title: SF hospital tests new goo in walls to absorb earthquake shock
text:
Photo: Paul Chinn, The Chronicle print_article_embed|photo-8543577|article-6479235|7 comments_jump_embed|photo-8543577|article-6479235|1 email_share_embed|photo-8543577|article-6479235|1 facebook_share_embed|photo-8543577|article-6479235|2 twitter_share_embed|photo-8543577|article-6479235|3 pinterest_share_embed|photo-8543577|article-6479235|4 reddit_share_embed|photo-8543577|article-6479235|5 google_share_embed|photo-8543577|article-6479235|6 A construction crew works inside the pedestrian tunnel below Van Ness Avenue for the California Pacific Medical Center hospital project in San Francisco, Calif. on Thursday, Aug. 27, 2015. Structural engineers are bolting 119 viscous wall dampers in the exterior walls to minimize or eliminate damage during a major earthquake. A construction crew works inside the pedestrian tunnel below Van...
The new California Pacific Medical Center under construction on Van Ness Avenue has installed an earthquake shock absorber system built around a goo-like substance with the consistency (and stickiness) of a wad of chewed bubble gum. A construction crew works inside the pedestrian tunnel below Van Ness Avenue for the California Pacific Medical Center hospital project in San Francisco, Calif. on Thursday, Aug. 27, 2015. Structural engineers are bolting 119 viscous wall dampers in the exterior walls to minimize or eliminate damage during a major earthquake. The new California Pacific Medical Center under construction on Van Ness Avenue has installed an earthquake shock absorber system built around a goo-like substance with the consistency (and stickiness) of a wad of chewed bubble gum.
